tool.name: gnutls-cli
tool.title: GnuTLS client
tool.description: Simple client program to set up a TLS connection.
tool.detail:
Simple client program to set up a TLS connection to some other computer. 
It sets up a TLS connection and forwards data from the standard input to the secured socket and vice versa.
tool.short-usage:
Usage: gnutls-cli [options] hostname
gnutls-cli --help for usage instructions.

options.description: Enable debugging
options.detail: Specifies the debug level.

options.description: More verbose output
Enable trust on first use authentication
options.detail:
This option will, in addition to certificate authentication, perform authentication
based on previously seen public keys, a model similar to SSH authentication. Note that when tofu 
is specified (PKI) and DANE authentication will become advisory to assist the public key acceptance
process.

options.description: Fail to connect if a certificate is unknown or a known certificate has changed
options.detail: This option will perform authentication as with option --tofu; however, no questions shall be asked whatsoever, neither to accept an unknown certificate nor a changed one.

options.description: Enable DANE certificate verification (DNSSEC)
options.detail:
This option will, in addition to certificate authentication using 
the trusted CAs, verify the server certificates using on the DANE information
available via DNSSEC.

options.description: Use the local DNS server for DNSSEC resolving
options.detail:
This option will use the local DNS server for DNSSEC.
This is disabled by default due to many servers not allowing DNSSEC.

options.description: Enable CA certificate verification
options.detail: This option can be used to enable or disable CA certificate verification. It is to be used with the --dane or --tofu options.

options.description: Enable OCSP certificate verification
options.detail: This option will enable verification of the peer's certificate using ocsp

options.description: Establish a session and resume
options.detail: Connect, establish a session, reconnect and resume.

options.description: Send early data on resumption from the specified file
Establish a session and rehandshake
options.detail: Connect, establish a session and rehandshake immediately.

options.description: Server's hostname for server name indication extension
options.detail: Set explicitly the server name used in the TLS server name indication extension. That is useful when testing with servers setup on different DNS name than the intended. If not specified, the provided hostname is used. Even with this option server certificate verification still uses the hostname passed on the main commandline. Use --verify-hostname to change this.

options.description: Server's hostname to use for validation
options.detail: Set explicitly the server name to be used when validating the server's certificate.

options.description: Connect, establish a plain session and start TLS
options.detail: The TLS session will be initiated when EOF or a SIGALRM is received.

options.description: The application protocol to be used to obtain the server's certificate (https, ftp, smtp, imap, ldap, xmpp, lmtp, pop3, nntp, sieve, postgres)
options.detail: Specify the application layer protocol for STARTTLS. If the protocol is supported, gnutls-cli will proceed to the TLS negotiation.

options.description: Use DTLS (datagram TLS) over UDP
Set MTU for datagram TLS
Send CR LF instead of LF
Enable TCP Fast Open
Use DER format for certificates to read from
Print peer's certificate in PEM format
Save the peer's certificate chain in the specified file in PEM format
Save the peer's OCSP status response in the provided file
Save all OCSP responses provided by the peer in this file
options.detail: The file will contain a list of PEM encoded OCSP status responses if any were provided by the peer, starting with the one for the peer's server certificate.

options.description: Save the server-side TLS message trace in the provided file
Save the client-side TLS message trace in the provided file
The minimum number of bits allowed for DH
options.detail: This option sets the minimum number of bits allowed for a Diffie-Hellman key exchange. You may want to lower the default value if the peer sends a weak prime and you get an connection error with unacceptable prime.

options.description: Priorities string
options.detail:
TLS algorithms and protocols to enable. You can
use predefined sets of ciphersuites such as PERFORMANCE,
NORMAL, PFS, SECURE128, SECURE256. The default is NORMAL.

Check  the  GnuTLS  manual  on  section  ``Priority strings'' for more
information on the allowed keywords

options.description: Certificate file or PKCS #11 URL to use
CRL file to use
X.509 key file or PKCS #11 URL to use
X.509 Certificate file or PKCS #11 URL to use
Private key file (PKCS #8 or PKCS #12) or PKCS #11 URL to use
options.detail:
In order to instruct the application to negotiate raw public keys one
must enable the respective certificate types via the priority strings (i.e. CTYPE-CLI-*
and CTYPE-SRV-* flags).

Check  the  GnuTLS  manual  on  section  ``Priority strings'' for more
information on how to set certificate types.

options.description: Raw public-key file to use
options.detail:
In order to instruct the application to negotiate raw public keys one
must enable the respective certificate types via the priority strings (i.e. CTYPE-CLI-*
and CTYPE-SRV-* flags).

Check  the  GnuTLS  manual  on  section  ``Priority strings'' for more
information on how to set certificate types.

options.description: SRP username to use
SRP password to use
PSK username to use
PSK key (in hex) to use
The port or service to connect to
Don't abort program if server certificate can't be validated
Allow broken algorithms, such as MD5 for certificate verification
Use length-hiding padding to prevent traffic analysis
options.detail: When possible (e.g., when using CBC ciphersuites), use length-hiding padding to prevent traffic analysis.

options.description: Benchmark individual ciphers
options.detail: By default the benchmarked ciphers will utilize any capabilities of the local CPU to improve performance. To test against the raw software implementation set the environment variable GNUTLS_CPUID_OVERRIDE to 0x1.

options.description: Benchmark TLS key exchange methods
Benchmark TLS ciphers
options.detail: By default the benchmarked ciphers will utilize any capabilities of the local CPU to improve performance. To test against the raw software implementation set the environment variable GNUTLS_CPUID_OVERRIDE to 0x1.

options.description: Print a list of the supported algorithms and modes
options.detail: Print a list of the supported algorithms and modes. If a priority string is given then only the enabled ciphersuites are shown.

options.description: Print a list of the supported priority strings
options.detail: Print a list of the supported priority strings. The ciphersuites corresponding to each priority string can be examined using -l -p.

options.description: Don't allow session tickets
options.detail: Disable the request of receiving of session tickets under TLS1.2 or earlier

options.description: Offer SRTP profiles
Application layer protocol
options.detail: This option will set and enable the Application Layer Protocol Negotiation  (ALPN) in the TLS protocol.

options.description: Compress certificate
options.detail: This option sets a supported compression method for certificate compression.

options.description: Activate heartbeat support
The maximum record size to advertise
Do not send a Server Name Indication (SNI)
Disable all the TLS extensions
options.detail: This option disables all TLS extensions. Deprecated option. Use the priority string.

options.description: Send a single key share under TLS1.3
options.detail:
This option switches the default mode of sending multiple
key shares, to send a single one (the top one).

options.description: Enable post-handshake authentication under TLS1.3
options.detail: This option enables post-handshake authentication when under TLS1.3.

options.description: Inline commands of the form ^<cmd>^
options.detail: Enable inline commands of the form ^<cmd>^. The inline commands are expected to be in a line by themselves. The available commands are: resume, rekey1 (local rekey), rekey (rekey on both peers) and renegotiate.

options.description: Change the default delimiter for inline commands
options.detail: Change the default delimiter (^) used for inline commands. The delimiter is expected to be a single US-ASCII character (octets 0 - 127). This option is only relevant if inline commands are enabled via the inline-commands option

options.description: Specify the PKCS #11 provider library
options.detail: This will override the default options in /etc/gnutls/pkcs11.conf

options.description: Reports the status of the FIPS140-2 mode in gnutls library
Reports the configuration of the library
Redirect informational messages to a specific file
options.detail: Redirect informational messages to a specific file. The file may be /dev/null also to make the gnutls client quiet to use it in piped server connections where only the server communication may appear on stdout.

options.description: Label used for exporting keying material
Size of the exported keying material
Block waiting for the resumption data under TLS1.3
options.detail: This option makes the client to block waiting for the resumption data under TLS1.3. The option has effect only when --resume is provided.

options.description: Enable automatic retrieval of missing CA certificates
options.detail: This option enables the client to automatically retrieve the missing intermediate CA certificates in the certificate chain, based on the Authority Information Access (AIA) extension.
